Situation1: The passenger’s train leaves soon and the station is across town
Expectation2: Arrive at the polling station during designated voting hours
Situation2: Polls stay open all day and the voter has a light schedule.
Story: I glanced at the dashboard clock as my passenger anxiously tapped his foot in the back seat. “My train leaves in twenty minutes,” he said, voice tight. The station was clear across town, and traffic was already thickening. As a taxi driver, I knew my job was to get him there safely and on time, but I also couldn’t ignore the polling station just a few blocks away. Today was election day, and I’d promised myself I’d vote—civic duty, my parents’ voices echoed in my head. The polls were open all day, and my schedule was light, but if I took this detour now, I’d risk my passenger missing his train. If I waited until after, I might get caught up with more fares and miss my chance to vote. My hands tightened on the wheel as I weighed the responsibility to my passenger against my responsibility as a citizen. The light turned green, and I hesitated, heart pounding, torn between two roads and the expectations waiting at the end of each.
